None of the wierd sweetness that a lot of macro lagers have.  Makes you wonder if American macro and regional lagers used to taste like this.  Ill stock my fridge with this for guests who just want a normal beer, and I suspect Ill down a few of these with burgers and dogs at my next cookout.
I believe this is the first pilsener Ive rated.  Light yellow color, medium head, medium carbonation.  Smooth taste.  Hoppy with nice finish.  Nothing to write home about, but a nice beer.
Tasted at Stone Brewery.  Clear yellow with frothy white head.  Hoppy floral aroma and crisp clean finish.  A good hot weather beer.

UPDATED: JUN 13, 2007 Clear golden pour with a tight bubble white head. Lemon grass and bready on the nose. Very authentic pilsner flavors with plenty of euro hops and biscuity maltiness. Finishes dry and crisp. A very tasty brew.

Pours a very light crystal clear straw with a nice white head.  It smells like hops, lemon, apricot, and cotton candy.  Lightly carbonated but fairly crisp.  Flavors are pretty straight forward.  A little doughy yeasty malt, grassiness and straight to the hops.  Its very close to Pilsner Urquell, but cleaner.

Rated 7/25/06:  I rated this beer based more on style than on my preferences. Aroma is crisp with a friendly bite to it, sweet and hoppy could be more pronounced. Poured a very pale golden yellow with an enormous white pillowy head that left some impressive lacing down my glass. Clean mouthfeel that is wonderfully smooth which teams with the flavor to make this beer incredibly drinkable. Flavor falls right in line with a nice crisp and snappy profile. The hops (I believe saaz are commonly used) round out a lightly malted base creating a nicely balanced flavor. There is a beautiful easiness to this pilsner ( I dont want to call it simple ) which is what makes it so very good and easily enjoyable. Not my favorite style and for the price I will likely not re-visit this too often.

Light color, yellowish.  German malts come through, tastes very pilsenerish.  Malts are nicely complemented by the presence of hops.  This is really the first good pilsener that Ive had, and Id probably enjoy it on a hot summer day.

Pours a very light yellow/straw with a thick white head that fades to a lasting thin bead. The aroma is Saaz hops (floral, spicey) balanced by sweet, honey-like malt aroma. The beer begins very malty on the tip of the tongue. The middle of the tongue picks up lots and lots of saaz bitterness, some malts, and some lager yeast. The bottle I am sampling now is mostly clean in the malt flavor - but one I tried the other day had loads of diactyl (which is perhaps intentional as this is a characteristic shared by Pilsner Urquell). The finish is dry and crisp with a lingering spicey bitterness. The mouthfeel is medium in body, and quite dry as it coats the tongue as well as quite bubbly.

A beautiful pilsner.  Clear gold with a bubbly white head.  The aroma explodes with hops, grass, and lemons.  Clean, crisp taste that perfectly balances the malt and noble hops.  Dry, sweet finish.  Very, very good beer.

Probably the best pilsner Ive had.  Brilliant golden color in the glass.  Very grassy aroma.  The flavor is light with a hint of sourness in the background.  The hop presence that bitters the finish is excellent.  My first brew from Victory.  Im glad they are selling in Georgia.

This is pretty much one of the better pilseners out there. I had it before one time, but now I actually remember it a lot better. It looks pretty nice with a rather pale carbonated body and a nice frothy white head for a lager. Nice smell that definitely tells you exactly how the beer will taste when you start drinking it. Has a sort of nippy dry taste in the mouth, but there is definitely a quality hope presence. There really is not much to complain about with this beer except that you ran out of said beer.

Poured from the tap to a sparkling light yellow, whith snow white head that linered thru mid-glass and left okay lacing. Aroma wasnt as pronounced as I thought it would be, but tended to be grassy citrus. Mouthfeel nipping due to the carbonation, and the flavor was a continuation of the grassy fruit found in the aroma. 

Im not a big pilsner fan generally, but must say Victory did a good job on this one.
light gold with a fizzy white head.  nice sweet malty aroma with a definite hop presence.  nice and bitter with an excellent texture and bready backbone.

Gold yellow pour with a creamy white head.  Pretty strong aroma of citrus, grass, toast and hay.  Nicely carbonated.  Taste is very fresh and there is some faint lemon and floral notes.  Very earthy beer with balancing malt and a crisp finish.  Makes me want to get a pilsener glass.  Great rendition of the style and mighty tasty.

I went to the Victory Brewery in Downingtown and bought a jug of Prima Pils to have with dinner. It pours nicely with a small head. The taste starts off well but fades into the nastiest metallic finish I have ever experienced. Very unpleasant.

Bottle. Pours clear, light golden yellow. Aroma is BIG! Lemon, grassy hoppiness. Slight cookie aroma from the pale malt perhaps?  Taste is crisp, tart, refreshing with slight hops bitterness in the end. Not sure the variety of hops but they work well in this Pils. Great summer beer, very enjoyable and easy drinking.
On tap, nice medium amber, no head to speak op. Big Sazz Boquet. Big hop flavor with some malty sweetness and some fruity undertones. Light to medium mouth feel, great Plz.

Victory Prima Pils is a sparkling, intense and clear light golden lager with a slowly dissipating small white head.  The lacing is thick and persistent.  The aroma is fruity, soft and wooden.  There is a faint bright citrus note.  Light grain provides the backdrop for these noble players.  It is tender to the tounge when wet, but leaves a chalky feel.  It has a nice, filling medium body.  The hops burst onto the scene here, fruity and wooden.  It is a loud and bright flavor that persists with the rumble of peppry alcohol and bitter juniper.  Wow!  A light lager can be unoffensive... and wonderful!  Par for the course for Victory.
Great beer to have when everyone else is drinking big 3.....this will be my summer beer on tap at the apartment...can drink all night and not wake up in the hospital
Lots of hops, and a little bitter. A pretty good beer, but nothing amazing.
Far from my style of beer I guess when I drink a pils I actually expect more of a swill style which this is not. Slight hopnes to it for me all I really notice is the sourness of it.

12 ounce bottle into a pilsner glass, pale golden with a medium white head. Aroma was a big dose of hops with a touch of malt. The flavor was much the same with the hops dominating, but a bit of malt coming through. There was some bitterness on the finish.

Bottled.  Overall a really good pilsner.  Pours light yellow with small head and large bubbles.  Smells of lemon and grass and hops.  The taste is a great mix of citrus of hops which goes down smooth yet fulfilling.

UPDATED: JUN 28, 2008 Tap at Barcade: Golden beer, with perfect clarity and topped a white consistent film. The aroma is bright with light citrus hop notes, predominately lemon, grassy notes and a pale malt hint. Flavor is similiar. Crisp, with evident smooth lemon-hop notes, with enough malt character to hold the body. Bright and clean with a smooth bitter finish. Solid Pilsener profile.

Poured into a pilsner glass with a frothy thick white head and medium golden colour. Lasting head and lacing of the glass. Aroma is citrus, grassy, & hops. Starts with crispy taste with citrus and pils malts. Dry texture, slight watery body, a light beer.
bottle thanks to thaichile...pours clear golden yellow, thick foamy head, huge carbonated bubbles... tastes very floral and bitter, pretty good for a bottom fermented brew

I did not like this beer at all. The aroma was especially unpleasant. It had a crisp, citrus taste that was kind of strange. Compared to other beers, it tasted watery and thin. I think some might reconsider high ratings when it is compared alongside stronger beers.
Brilliant clear golden with a thick snow white head.  Lots of hops in the nose.  Loads of pilsner malt.  Long earthy  hop flavor and bitternes.  Crisp.  Thirst quencher.

UPDATED: MAR 27, 2009 Bottle, pour is clear with a close to medium gold color, a white head that diminishes to a ring and cover, there is some effervescence in the glass, light faint particles in the bottle, aroma of pilsener malt, honey sweetness, has the lemon sour citrus with some sugar-honey sweetness fragrances, dry grassy light bitter hops with malt, bread and sweet bread flavors, citrus and lemon skin oil flavor with a light sugar-honey sweetness, bitterness lingers after the finish, finish is dry and has a lemon citrus touch with a touch of sour bread flavor and faint sweetness,
a nice dry lemony citrus flavored pilsner.

Had this back to back with Troegs Sunshine Pils. While I liked the Troegs better, this was tastier and hoppier. More hops than any pilsener Ive ever had. Pour was a bubbly gold with a quick thin white head. Aroma of slight hops. Taste of hops and lemon with a crisp dry finish. This is a summer beer all the way!
user_location: Moon Twp, suburb of Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Bottle.  Average white head (fully diminishes).  Clear (flat looking) golden body.  Flowery hops, lemon, and honey aromas.  Flavor is initially a sweet sour and finishes...pretty much the same.  Suprised by the long duration on the finish.  Light bodied.  Watery to dry textured.  Lively carbonation.  Very light beer but very refreshing....why couldnt it be a hot day, instead of this cold snap NC is having!
I have to concur with my colleagues. Citrus flavor and hop bitterness made this one of the most refreshing beers Ive had.
light golden color with a foamy head.aromas of lemony hops and grass.lots of great hop flavor grass, citrus, pine...awsome. perfect lawnmower beer.

Another rating against the grain.  This one did not set well with me and may deserve another sample.  This bottled brew from a bottle shop poured a small sized head of foamy finely sized white colored bubbles that were mostly lasting and left behind a slightly hazy typically carbonated yellow-orange colored body and a fair lacing. The mild aroma was malty and dirty sock. The mouth feel was tingly at the start and at the finish. The strange weird off the mark flavor contained notes of leathery malt and hop. A horrible one that I would rather not drink again.

The beer-snobs pilsener...  This is, without a doubt, the best pils Ive ever had.  Its only technical flaw is that it doesnt follow the normal hopping rate of a true pilsener (true to style pilseners are usually slightly hoppier than normal lagers... This brew, however, pushes beyond the limits of normal pilsener hopping levels and actually has a an IBU level that could compete with a pale ale).  That being said... I dont care, its still the best pils Ive ever had.  Perfect color, as much malt & hop flavor as you can get from a pils, and completely refreshing.  Another great job from Victory!
UPDATED: MAR 31, 2007 Golden pour with a white heat. Mild hop aromarn. Mild flower taste with a dry finish. This was just ok for me.

WHAT CAN YOU SAY! ITS THE BEST. GOOD MOUTHFEEL. REFRESHING. A CLEAN INTERESTINGLY BITTER, HOPPY TASTE. CITRUSY SWEET CHEESEBREAD IN THE BACKROUND. THE VERY BEST CARBONATION YOU CAN FIND IN A BEER.  DRINK IT IN THE SUMMER. VICTORY DOES EVERYTHING PERFECTLY.
Golden pour, frothy diminishing head, pretty hoppy for a pilsner, lively carbonation, smooth, not too much of a bitter/metallic aftertaste, enjoyable, my favorite from Victory at this point.
Bottle - very good pilsner full of flavor and more hops than you would expect from the style.
Pale amber color, More hop character than Id expect from a pilsner but very smoth and not the least bit bitter.

Tap @ Draught House Pub, Austin. Disgusting--although Im pretty sure the rancid taste was the pubs fault for serving it (I suspect) in a dirty glass. Smelled like the zoo. Since Ive heard such great things about it I will try it again and then re-rate.

Bottle.  Bright, lemon-yellow color. 1/4" foam.  Lightly fruity, distinctive hops aroma, somewhat bready.  Pleasant taste wave washes steadily through roof of mouth and base of throat.  One of the best pilseners Ive ever had.
Pilsner glass.  Nice golden color.  Perfume aroma is hoppy for a Pilsner.  Well balanced  hop to malt ratio in taste.  Nice dry bitter finnish.

pours a crystal clear unimpressive straw color with an inch thick white head with mild retention and good lacing. Smells of grass, lemon, and not much else. Very nice on the palate. Its slightly fuller than I expected and dry from start to finish. The active carbonation is nice and spritzy. A peculiar hop bitterness emerges in the finish that lingers in the back of the mouth. A great, malty, surprisingly hoppy pils by which all other pilsners should be judged.

this is good pilsener, the head on it is ok does not retain very well. flavor is average and has a decent bite to it. there is a different kind of bitterness to it that makes it unique and easy to drink
Pours like a standard pilsner. Hops are more apparent than your average pilsner.  Very nice summer beer.

UPDATED: MAR 3, 2011 On tap at Tylers, Durham. Very lively pilsener, heavier on the hops than some versions of the style. Golden and quite effervescent, this one is popping right from the start - and the floral hops slowly emerge from the overall dryness. Excellent session brew.
UPDATED: NOV 21, 2008 The standard by which pilsner should be measured by. Hoppy malty and I wish every yellow bubbly was this good. 479 of Michael Jacksons Great Beer Guide.
12oz bottle pours a clear golden color with a little white head. This is my favorite pilsner, because it doesnt taste much like a pilsner.
Best tasting pilsner Ive ever had.  That being said, it tasted more like an IPA with a bit of corniness to remind you its a pilsner.  Not very representative of a pilsner.  Not much head.

12oz. Bottle

Prima Pils poured a very pale golden. Crystal clear with a 1 finger eggshell white head. The head sticks on this one. Moderate carbonation rises in random spots off the bottom.

Smells of grain with a touch of sweetness. Theres also a little hay in the nose as as well. A nice noble hop spiciness comes through at the end.

Taste is good. Like a pilsner but the flavors seem to be more pronounced than most which is a plus. Theres hay/grassy flavor throughout that balances with the graininess in the back. The hop spiciness comes through at the swallow. This is all followed up by a nice mild but lingering bitterness that makes you want to take that next gulp.

Mouthfeel is where it should be. Light but not watery. Carbonation pushes it through. 

Drinkability is high. The body and mouthfeel make it an easy drinker and the hops leave a nice lingering bite that leaves you wanting more. Very dry finish.

Sampled 10/13/06
Bottle.  Moderate malt and orange/pineapple hops aroma.  Golden yellow with small head.  Sweet orange and pineapple hops flavor.   A nice enough beer - fairly hoppy.

12 oz brown bottle.  Pop lid for a musty yeast arome, in a good way.  Pours like any other common pale yellow american beer. has a shallow froth on top. Initially the flavor is fruity hoppy.  Not real bitter hoppy.  Taste is much better than the label indicates. As you drink,  the bitterness in the finish begins to build. Good creamy micro bubble palate. Pretty enjoyable, except for that medium hoppy kick. It leaves you bitter for a few moments after the last sip.  Rather enjoyable for a hoppy brew but less enjoyable than a well behaved gentlemans lager. Not as good as Bavik, but OK. Right along side of Schell and Urquell.
user_location: Beaver Valley, Beaver County, Pennsylvania, USA

text: very hoppy aroma/flavor...goes down fairly smooth...definately a good beer to drink

Poured a very vibrant, almost neon yellow. Very little or no head. Extremely hoppy aroma, sharp grassy scent as well. Reminds me a bit of St. Pauli Girl in aroma. Mouthfeel was very bubbly; high carbonation indeed. Taste was grassy and slightly citrus-like. Not my cup of beer, so to speak, but well-made I suppose. Left a very scratchy sore throat as a reminder of why I usually dont drink light German-style beers.

UPDATED: MAY 26, 2009 ++++ Re Rate 25 May 2009 ++++
12 oz bottle courtesy of alagnak.  Enjoy by Mar 28 09 stamped on the label. Pour is hazed yellow golden with a one inch pure white head. Nice splotchy lacing. Aroma of grassy hops, earth malt behind that, some light clove yeastiness. Nice nose. Taste is the ester clove hop grass and teastiness. Nice full earthy resin malt backbone. Palate is medium thin, prickly carbonation, really drinkable. (8,4,7,4,15 - 3.8)

++++ Original Rating 20 Feb 2007 ++++
Bottle. Pour is golden, with a nice white head that settles quickly. Aroma is hops, though somewhat faint. Taste, is crisp, clean and bright hops. Very, very refreshing brew. I wish it was summer! My favorite Pilsener right now..  (6,4,8,4,15 - 3.7)
grapefruit, hops, easy to drink, good head, ligh, refreshing, one of the better ones ive had in some time
Very hoppy beer here, but not much else. The aroma is all hops. The flavor doesnt have any malt in it but that is to be expected from a pilsener. A good pilsener, but not my favorite style.

This beer is very good.  It tastes much like a good Bohemian Pilsner, like a Pilsner Urquell or a Czechvar.

It pours a pale, dull, yellow with decent head formation which dissipates quickly but leaves good lacing.  At first I was afraid I smelled a bit of skunkiness, but I believe that was just generous amounts of Saaz hops.  Flavor is fairly light, but definitely "European" in character.  At first I thought it didnt taste like much, but as I drank it, significant pleasant bitterness accumulated in my mouth.  Mouthfeel is light, but not insubstantial.  This beer is extremely drinkable.
Bottle.  Aroma of citrus, yeast, and malt.  Very nice mouthfeel.  Flavor similar to the smell with some noticable bittering hops.
a very hoppy beer with little else to offer. i wasnt impressed by the flavor and it didnt last.
wow!  this is what crapy beer should taste like.  its kind of like the flavor of a natural light times 100.  in a good way.  i shall drink many more of these...

Pours out a light golden color, formed a small white foamy head.  Aroma of hops, yeast.  Typical pilsner flavor with a light bitter hoppish ending.  Clean and refreshing beer.  Not my personal style of beer, but I can imagine drinking about 9 of these on a hot summer day while mowing the lawn.  Victory is another great American brewery.
user_location: The Crystal Coast, North Carolina, USA

text: bottle from abusedgoat: pours golden hay colour little white head nice hop aroma and some sweet fruit and yeast nice flavour o f bittering hops some yeast flavour too finish dry. very nice for a style i dont normally drink.

Nice clean and fresh tasting beer. I am so used to drinking dark, heavy beers, that when I drank my first glass of Victory Prima Pils, I was underwhelmed.  It tasted like a light beer.  I was primed for a bitter, hoppy beer, but the flavor was well balanced; a bit dry; but very drinkable.  Nice.

Bottle. White fizzy head that fully dissipated, no lacing, transparent, visible carbonation, and a pale yellow hue. Malty and hoppy nose and ditto for the flavor. Finishes dry. Mouthfeel was tingly. Light-medium body. Decent for the style and quaffable. Just one that didnt set the world on fire for me.
Earthy scents, reminds me of being on the farm.  Light, pale colour, fizzy.  Weak head.  Hoppy inoffensive flavour.  Overall a solid beer.

Pours a nice golden color, very slightly hazed, and topped by about an inch of white foam. Moderate head retention, no real lacing. Nice hoppy aroma  quite spicy actually.

The flavor is very pleasant with crisp and clean lightly toasted malt and spicy bitter hops. Medium bodied and nicely carbonated. Drinkable? Oh yeah  big time. I have said in the past that I look forward to brewpubs releasing a pils because there is nothing quite like a freshly made version. Well, now I take that back because every time I drink this beer (which is fairly often lately) I just cant get over how fresh and sharp and tangy and clean it tastes.
THIS IS PROBABLY A GREAT BEER. IT HAS WON MANY AWARDS.  i JUST AM NOT A PILSNER FAN.  IT DOES HAVE AN INTENSE BITE TO IT.
smells like well pilsner.  pours a very light yellow.  very clean taste, nice crispness.  not avery good aftertaste though.  its ok

Pours flat light yellow, with a small frothy white head.  Aroma is nice hay, straw, leather, apple esters.  Flavor starts well balanced and finishes more hoppy and bitter.  Light to medium bodied, watery, livley, refreshing.

The aroma is a light hoppy lemon/lime. The head is creamy for a minute, off white, not much lacing and the head is fully diminishing. The body is clear and yellow/gold in color. The initial flavor is a little acidic with a hint of bitter, the finish is about the same and average in duration. The body is light, watery with lively carbonation. The final finish does leave a good taste.

Pours a fairly clear gold; head was white, medium in size.  Aroma is a little bit yeasty, earthy, some mild spice, and light hops.  Refreshing, earthy flavor.  Hops dominate the flavor; some light breadiness.  Dry finish.  Very good for style.

Right from the Victory Brewery tap.  Poured a nice light clear and golden yellow.  The head does not stay long but there is lacing from start to finish.  The hop aroma is wonderful and spicy.  The carbonation is not overbearing and is a pleasant change from those less carbonated heavy beers.  The hop flavors dominate initially but give way to a bready/malty bitter finish.  This beer is very drinkable, light and refreshing and does not overdue the bitterness.  I dont consider myself a "hop-head" but this beer just does it right.  Excellent!

Pours the color of hay, kinda cloudy, and with a head that is respectable but temporary.  Smells fresh like an open field, just nice and grassy, and ever so slightly sweet.  Reminds one of pale lager aromas, without the "ass" factor messing things up.  Taste has modest, slighty sweet earthy malt character, but the hops are clearly evdient in the flavor.  Theres a grassiness to the flavor, but the finish becomes very dry with an IPA-like bitterness.  This finish could cut through any amount of horseradish Id put on my sandwiches.  I hated the Hop Wallop finish, and while this beer reminds me of that, its much more modest and delightful.  What more could you want from a Pilsner?
UPDATED: OCT 25, 2007 Mostly clear straw color with a huge head. Spare lacing. Aroma of sugary malts, grass and perfume hops. Pleasant bitterness in the taste. Very dry finish. Great beer.
Pours a golden straw with a wite head. Armoa is classic pilsner. Taste is dominated by hops, especially the finish.
Pours a very light golden yellow. High amounts of bubbles. Retains a good head. Aroma is a delightful German pilsner. Tastes like a hefty bitter hops. A very crisp finish. A nice beer.

Clear straw color with a small foamy head.  Fruity hops in the aroma with a bit of yeast spiciness.  Flavor is a big hit of bitter hops up front that fades into a very subtle malty background.  Long, dry, crisp, bitter  finish that wraps it up very nicely.  A bit more medium bodied than I prefer in a pilsener but with a nice sparkling carbonation.  A good, refreshing pilsener.

Bottle.  Straw colored pour with a thin white head.  Slight hoppy, yeasty aroma with some light fruit notes (apple).  Flavor is spicy but flat with a watery finish, but not so bad for a pilsner.  I really dont like lagers or pilsners, but this beer isnt too bad.  This is what the macros should work on, something like this.

I am rating this as a pilsner. Pilsners are not suppose to be bursting with flavor or aroma as far as I know, so I had to down-shift for this rating. Pours a medium-dark yellow, small-medium white head that resides somewhat quickly. Slight spicy aroma of hops. Subtle noble hops bite on the tongue which finishes strong. Leaves the hop bitter after taste. A great pilsner in my opinion. But it is not my style of beer I normally drink, so I had to "grade on a curve".

Bottle, pours a nice pale golden color with a thick white head.  Nice spicy aroma of noble hops with a hint of malt.  Clean dry flavor balanced with the nice hop flavor.  Medium mouthfeel and a crisp finish.  Overall a very nice pils.
user_location: The Land of Milk and Honey, Ohio, USA

text: My girlfriend chose this beer at Maxs Taphouse in Baltimore and I tried some of it too.  It poured a clear gold color with a moderate, light white head.  Flavor was somewhat sweet and had a dry, bitter finish.  I could not pick up much of the aroma, but it seemed to be grassy hops.  The beer was ok, just not one of my favorite styles.

THOUGHTS: Good for its style, but not the type of beer I like. Great bead rising up from the center of the bottom of the glass.
TECHNICAL: Poured a sparkling, clear, light yellow with a small to average white head that mostly diminished. The aroma was moderate metallic hops with may bee some flower/perfueme/herbs/grass notes. The initial flavor was lightly sweet and bitter, and the finish was heavily bitter and of average duration. The body was light and dry in the back of the mouth, but watery up fron. It had fizzy carbonation and a metallic finish
Bottle. A lot better than your average domestic pils. Its got that trademark victory hop aroma and flavor. Crisp and refreshing. A great domestic pilsner.

on tap at new place "The Comet" on Connecticut Ave. in DC just up the street from Chevy Chise Wine and Liquor. went there with my brothers, an Icelander and others. we were impressed by the few (very few) but very good beers on tap and the INCREDIBLE pizza. thats all they serve foodwise.  but its worth it.  anyways, very fresh. pours a slightly hazy yellow gold with a minimal white head that dissipates quickly. smells very pleasant. of white grape juice (like Welches from childhood - yummy!) as well as lemon and some other citrus hops. overall this is just a clean and refreshing beer. I was extremely impressed. crisp, dry with light dry citrus hops, lemons, slightly sweet, straw, herbs and finishes with a touch of yeast. so drinkable I drank two.

Every time Ive had this beer it tasted like it was skunked.  Ive given it four chances and decided that this must be the taste?  I do taste some good pilsener qualities in there but they seemed to be outweighed.  Could it really be just a skunky tasting beer?  Maybe Im just not experienced enough to enjoy this beer?  No more...No thanks.

Bottle.  Strong, grassy, floral hops in the nose.  Clear yellow pour with light carb and a fluffy white head.  Tasty bitterness balanced with peripheral sweetness.  Powerful taste just grabs you and refuses to let go.  Smooth mf, soft water, and a light bit along with the light body.  On the whole, high praise for this beer, probably the closest to a German Pils Ive had in the States, a lovely offering, though Ill wait a bit longer before crowning it the best in the country.

I bought this 6er despite my instinct to never buy a lager coated in dust... still, it seemed fresh.  Pours a clear golden yellow with no bubbles (great to see in a Pilsner) and a dense, but not excessive head.  The nose is big with bready yeasty aromas and a very obvious peppery to spicy aroma.  Very lightly sweet,  dry with some floral points.  The mouthfeel is dead on for the style.  Rather creamy and smooth, while not too viscous at all.  Doesnt seem watery, nice indeed.  The flavor is a step up from the aroma.  Dry and slightly astringent with obvious peppery spiciness from the hops.  The malt here really just provides a breadiness with some lightly toasted notes.  Really dry and drinkable.  Just in nailing down my notes Ive drank half a bottle.  The finish somehow creamy, while the aftertaste is again this spicy floral peppery sort of flavor.  I enjoyed this for the style, and Id gladly by this for  a party as the flavors arent too bold, while they certainly arent dumbed down at all. If it were only sold in my area...  Beats Pilsner Urquel any day!  (though the rare fresh Urquel comes close)

Aroma of bread, hay and a bit grassy. Golden, clear color with a arge white frothy head. Medium sweetness, lightly bitter, light body and long dry finish.  This is by far the best pilsener I have had in quite a while.

Poured a cloudy light yellow with a bright white head. To the nose, lemony citrus, hops and honey. To the palate...very hoppy. Stiking to the palate actually with flavours of bitter hopps and spice. Bitterness lasts right through to the palate. Refreshing but almost too hoppy.
Im not usualy into pilsner or any beer this light, but this was good. Kinda like a Pilsner/IPA mix. Good light flavor, tasty hops. Victory beers rule.

Slightly cloudy yellow-green pour, no head.  Aroma of lemon and hops, with some faint floral smells as well.  Taste of honey and lemon, nice full finish.  Im not really a pilsner fan, but this was excellent
Funky noble hop aromas, floral with lots of sour fruit. Big but delicate maltiness, surprising hop flavors and bitterness. The IPA of lagers!

12oz bottle from a variety pack.  Pours a golden yellow. I smell the lemon but not the orange as other have said.  very dry finish.
Not too bad.  will drink again..

UPDATED: DEC 19, 2006 Bottle. Pours a light orange to gold color with a large amount of uneven beige head. It is remarkably hazy in the glass, making it look like a hefeweizen rather than a typical pilsner. Powerful, intriguing, clean floral aroma, like a fine soap. Lemon and orange notes from the citrusy hops are evident. The aroma almost overwhelmed the flavor as I drank the beer. There is a bitter bite to the flavor on the first sip, but that quickly dissipates. The flavors are quite subdued, but the most evident one is floral hops. The taste is pleasant, but it is too weak. There is a nice bitter aftertaste. The beer is very smooth, clean, drinkable, and satisfying in the palate. My bottle was overcarbonated, and the beer overflowed when I removed the cap, but this problem did not seem to affect the palate. Still, I will deduct a point from the overall score for the offense. Prima Pils is a nice, well made beer. Its easy drinkability and subtlety suggest that it would hold up well to multiple drinkings, though I purchased just one bottle to taste. It is a fine choice if youre in the mood for an American pilsner.
sweet citrus on the nose, pine tar, and citrus on the palate with a slight bit of honey and a very (for a pilsner) hoppy bitter finish.  Best pilsner Ive had by a long shot.

Bottle.   Pours a clear golden color with a large thick head.   Aroma is citrus, toast, malt.   Flavor is roasted malt, earthy, hops.   Palate is light to medium, moderately carbonated, bitter and dry finish.   Nicely done.
Get some bitter hops in the aroma.Pours a light golden color with a white head.Malt and hops are noticable in the flavor.Medium to light body with a bitter hop finish.

12 oz bottle.  I have had this several times.  I really like pilseners and this is a good one.  I really dont get the super hoppiness of this beer that is so talked about.  I imagine they are using a Saaz variety and its just well hidden within this beer.  It does give you a lot of pucker, thats for sure.  Not bad, but there are better pilseners out there IMO.
The best thing about this beer was the aroms which was very sweet.  Other than that I just didnt care for it.  I like hoppy beers just not this one.
UPDATED: OCT 22, 2016 [Super fresh can from Paul - WILL REQUIRE A RERATE] great stuff. Love this clean hoppy pilsner.

Bottled - Served in a classic pilsner glass..   Pours a light golden color with a small white head... Nose is very citrusy.. with a pine hoppy scent... Flavor is hoppy/piney upfront with a nice bitter finish... very drinkable!!

Very classy pilsner indeed, one of the best ive tried yet. Refresshing, full bodied and very organic and true tasting beer. Very citrusy with limes, lemons and grapefruit. Flowery but crisp and refreshing finish. Excelent thirst quencher and great for the summertime.

Pours yellow with a huge three finger white head in my pilsener glass. 
Smells of hops pine and a bit of funk. Taste is hops at first then a bit of funk with that classic pilsener taste. I will say that the pilsener taste is more noticeable than any other beer of this style I have had so far. Taste is crisp with a nice bittering finish not too bad.

Victory Prima Pils
12 oz bottle
Medium pour in a Pilsner glass
Recent brewing, primed 11/06

Poured a hazy bright yellow with an average white mostly lasting frothy head.

Smelt of moderate bread, dough and perfume.

Taste was upfront moderate pine and light sweet pineapple followed by a  strong pine bitterness and a light white bread kick on an long bitter flowery  finish.  Palate was light to medium bodied, crisp and dry, fizzy and lightly astringent.

Overall, this is what a pilsner should taste like.  No doubt.

UPDATED: FEB 14, 2007 pours a real light yellow with a one finger head does not last long and has a light body. has a strong pilsener smell with small hops and malt. taste is strong pilsener nice light hops and malt. has small lacing and a little sediment as well. best pilsener i have had.

Somwhat hazy honey-gold.  Very nice lacing.

Aromas are quite herbal.

Feels soft on the palate, but it does have energy, with plenty of subtle malts and a pleasant citrus/herb hop profile.  The finish is the most attention-grabbing aspect in its length and impressive bitterness.

A great balance of flavor intensity with drinkability.
Nice. Lots of hops but still a bit watery and a faint mineral flavour at di not really work. I like the finish and mouth feel of capital speical pilsner more.

UPDATED: JUL 7, 2007 12 oz bottle shared with StompBrockmore - pours a pale gold with a solid white head that actually stayed throughout the glass.  Sweetish aroma, typical of a quality pils.  Flavour - excellent - crisp and dry, with that familiar pils bite, but theres more here - the huge hopping of this beer makes everything stand at attention and gives a beautiful sweet, full taste in the mouth without being cloying.  The finish is much the same, but with the hop bitterness fading into a malt sweetness that you can feel all the way down your throat.  Superb!

UPDATED: FEB 1, 2012 Pours light golden with a thin, fully receding white head. Aroma of grassy, herbal hops, bready lager yeast. Taste is very herbal, with notes of mint, intense noble hops and crackery pale malt. Resinous for a noble hop beer, but perfectly balanced. Mouthfeel is medium bodied, and slightly resinous with lively carbonation. Very well done pilsner!

12oz. bottle shared with VeloVampire - pours cystal clear golden yellow with a mediumish white head. Aroma is of hops and somewhat sweet, not all that disimilar to Pilsner Urquell. The flavour is smooth and considerably hoppy for the style, in wonderful balance with the malt. A sweetly bready finish follows, with some nice bitterness underneath. Very creamy and smooth in the mouth. The citrusy sweetness in the finish is beautifully done, I only wish that I could pick this up on a regular basis here in Ontario. This is an absolutely perfect thirst quencher and I could drink a lot of this. This is a very well done Pilsener, one of the best Ive had, if not the best.

UPDATED: JUL 8, 2009 12 oz bottle via shigadeyo (thanks!).Pours a semi hazy golden blonde with a small white head. Aroma is grainy, grassy hops, pears and a bit of yeast. Taste is very hoppy for a Pilsner. Bitter aftertaste. Thin body. Watery mouthfeel. Basically a bunch of hops in water....

7/8/2009-rerate-orig was 6/3/4/2/8 on 11/12/2006-wow either my palette has changed a LOT in almost 3 years, or this beer has gotten much better!
Pours a clear gold with an everage white head.  Nose is all saaz.oh wondrous saaz. THis is pils perfection. What i always imagined a VERY fresh Pilsner Urquell might be like.Umm this is world calss Pils perfection. Near perfect taste, mouthfeel, carbonation. me needs more!

This beer is hops throughout.  Both aroma and flavor are loaded with them.  There is some fruit in the aroma and some bitterness in the flavor as well.  It is pretty much a rock solid pilsner  but probably got points deducted for being one.  That is not one of my favorite styles.
Any beer that has a picture of a Hop Flower on the bottle has to be great, and this one is no exception.  Had 3 of them this week, and cant wait to get my hands on more of them.

The ambition behind Victorys Prima Pils is one I can truly appreciate, it is one I have sought since my humble beginnings and have yet to conclude. Many beers have done the job half-way and Prima Pils may be just another, but the pure vision that there could be such an accomplishment is what sometimes drives my advance. What I suggest, you surely know, as even the most primitive drinker appreciates its quenching, reposing and generally enjoyable qualities. Yet, when one has been acquainted to the opulent, ostentatious and nonetheless rewarding, it seems we always seek a more affable companion for day to day colloquy. To our Cro-Magnon that might be the canned micturition, but my utopical equivalent embraces more Beauty, from its visual form down through the gullet. Victory gave it a try, and deserves proper respect, but Prima Pils is not the avatar for me - though I do not doubt it could be the one for my antipodal alter ego. 


The pour itself is decidedly unspectacular, crystalline and sallow, merely redeemed by an adequate white puff above. The nose however is sweet and enticing, filled to the brim with luxuriant fruits. Pineapple, apricot, clementine and banana sail gently with esters and light malts characterized by bubble gum, vanilla and acacia honey. Hints of grain, noble hops and Gouda produce a complex addition to the aroma. The nectareous fragrance translates onto the palate gaining in the process a rasping character that turns our cottony clementine into sharp lemon and orange peel. Pineapple, honey and a hint of coriander travel upon the Saharan palate to reveal an explosion of noble hops in the aftertaste. The parched and vigorously carbonated texture is offputting to me, but Victorys effort is admirable Ill admit. The search is still on.
Thanks from asteele8.    Bright, crisp looking yellow pour.  Lemon pepper aroma.  Great pils.  Very dry, bitter finish.

UPDATED: JUL 18, 2007 I think this is overrated. A pilsner must be dry to be refreshing. Prima pils is badly oversweet. I didnt really like the hop balance either.

Yeah I was right on! OVERRATED

Probably my favorite Pilsner.  Well rounded and flavorful hops with a smooth and almost creamy undertone.  Pours pale yellow and is cloudy.  Strong white head that dissapates with time.  I loved the sweetness and creamy smoothness combined with quality hops and the perfect use of alcohol.  Definately pick up a six pack or pint sometime.

Bottle:  Pours a light golden color with a nice white head and great lacing.  Aroma is a mild doughiness with some hops and malt.  Taste is a clean breadlike maltiness with some hop tones, citrus, grass, and perhaps a bit of grain.  Nice clean finish, one of the best pilseners Ive tried to date.

Very good pilsner. Hoppy aroma with hints of citrus and floral.  Clear golden color with moderate head.  Taste was good, slightly bitter and the presence of the hops was notable.  Palate was good, somewhat dry on the finish with a light bitter duration.  Very good for a pilsner.
Yellow-white sudsy pour.  Strong corn-like aroma.  The taste is lemongrass malted with a oily hop taste.  Finishes dry and lemony.

UPDATED: OCT 13, 2007 I am always happy to have my perspective on things contorted, usually by way of a simple chat.  Lively debates and conversation are the only things maintaining the integrity of democracy against tides of bloviate ramblings and insouciant apathy.  Heck, I enjoy such talks even more if my world is turned up side down by them.  I may not sleep for a few nights, but Ill have come to terms with a formerly inconceivable concept it.  I love it.  Sadly, beer fails to carry the same weight of importance as political theory I think, though the latter would likely be naught without the former.  Still, I have had a beer that wrested my prejudice from its ensconced position betwixt the wrinkles of my brain, out and away.  You see, I have always equated pilsners with unpleasant experiences like attending to business at the DMV or watching quorum calls on C-SPAN.  These arent traumatic experiences or intense ones.  Rather, their enervating nature is a prolonged leeching of energy; a siphoning of my youthful exuberance and curiosity.  An hour of any of those three will put me in a glum mood for the whole day.  But the Victory Prima Pils, unlike other pilsners Ive had, did not  it was exactly the opposite.  It is a pretty ho-hum colored beer, clearer than an eye lens and topped with an aspen white head that reminds me of the fair mountains of Colorado.  Wafts of lemon, Coca-cola, orange, peanuts, cashews, clover honey, banana bread, lime, avocado, artichoke and the distinguishing smell of corn tortilla and fish tacos all pack together for an enlightening and startling smelling experience.  The taste is adroitly balanced, with a dry and slight bitterness overcastting a blush of orange bread frosting and semi-hoppy wheatiness.  The flavor is moderately toned and keeps its footing on a precarious edge.  It is a beer with a button up shirt, though the collar is relaxed and the tie loose.  What better way to drink it?  After a good sigh and a dramatic collapse into a chair the Prima Pils is a fine candidate for the post-work day drink  pleasant but nothing excessive to think about.

Cold 12oz bottle:  Pours a cloudy light golden color with a small, frothy alabaster head which dissipates quickly.  Aroma is of sweet malt, lemon, grass, and floral hops. Taste is bittersweet with citrus, floral and some sour notes. 
Strongly carbonated and crisp.  If honey was added to this, it would be even better.

UPDATED: APR 16, 2009 Pours golden with small, but sufficent, frothy white head. Aroma of floral/grassy hops and some underlying malts. Flavor is crisp floral hops, a little bit of hoppy spice, and very balancing yeast like sweetness. Palate is medium and bitter with a bit of a resiny feel. Damn fine pilsener

Bottle. Its nice to see this one becoming available locally.

Pours a beautiful clear gold with a foamy whipped egg-white head. The aroma is grassy hops and bready malt, some yeast. The yeast flavors come through quite powerfully in a spicy orangy fruity flavor that almost veers toward a bitter wit; the finish makes it intentions quite clear as we get a lovely long bitterness only slighttly metallic. Mouthfeel is great, and Ive become a fan even if this isnt what Id consider quite a classic example of the style.

UPDATED: OCT 13, 2006 12 oz bottle.  Pours a clear light yellow with a decent frothy white head that retains well and laces the glass.

The aroma is light grains and noble hops.  Its clean, but not too exciting.

The flavor is slightly sweet, grainy malts with a good sized noble hop bitterness in the finish.  The mouthfeel is medium, with a good level of carbonation. 

Overall, a very well made, bold pilsner.  Im not a huge fan of the style though.

From the bottle, it pours straw colored with a thin white head.  Aromas come off as wheaty and field of grains like.  The flavor is a little wheaty and sweet but still with some complexities,  a little woody and balancing with hop bitterness.  Im not a pilsner person, but if more tasted like this i might become more of one.

On draught at restaurant.  Clear gold colour with large white head, looks like a pilsner as drawn by an artist.  Herbal nose.  Malty flavour with full taste.  Fine finish long and dry.  This is a wonderful pilsner. I loved it.
user_location: Munchen an der Willamette, Oregon, USA

text: Looks very clear as you pour it, like water but ends up like gold in the glass with medium foamy white head and beautiful lacing. Aroma is a mellow maltiness, a bit herbal and floral. Very smooth hoppy taste, Gotta be some cascade in here. Medium bitterness, that subsides quickly beaconning for another taste. Finishes with a nice bitter on the tongue and very gentle warming. I would enjoy this as an everyday beer due to the low alcohol content. Gotta be my favorite Pilsener by far.

Bottle poured a clear pale yellow with a diminishing white head. Aromas of bread, straw, light citrus and a hint of corn. Palate was light bodied and crisp. Flavors of straw, graininess and light citrus with a crisp lightly bitter finish.

One of my least favorite styles (probably from too many bad ones in college), but this one I can at least enjoy. The flavor is nice with notes of citrusy hops and bread/yeast. Another winner for Victory.
This was my first from victory brewing, and wow was it good.  Just a really nice tasting pilsener.

The operative word here is clean, in every respect.  Pours a golden yellow with a small frothy white head.  Aroma is noticeably subdued, breadiness and a hint of hop citrus predominate.  Taste is the definition of clean:  citrus hop is supported by a noticeable malty backbone, with a slightly bitter finish.  Sometimes simplicity is best.

Clear urine pour,with a frothy white head.  Classic pilsner in other words.  A little copper and yeast in the nose.  Suprising  amount of hops flavor.  Coppery aftertaste, but  really good for a pils.

Bottle. Pours a very light yellow color with a white head on top. Aroma is hops, grains, and bread. Flavor is hops, yeast, and grains.  Pretty tasty even though there are not very many flavors. A decent beer.

Bottle, a gift from Odeed! Nose is of some citrus, some grainy maltiness, with a tiny hint of tartness; Hazy urine yellow with a small white head; Flavor shows the citrusy hops, a little yeastyness and a  noce bitter hop finish along with the tongue-tingling palate.Tastes a lot more appetizing than it looks!

Bottled. Beer is clear, medium gold colored with a small, frothy, white, mostly diminishing head. The aroma is malty with moderate notes of slightly husky toasted grain, toasted bread, trace of toasted almond; Hoppy with  moderate notes of resin/pine, lemon zest; Yeasty with a moderate note of wet bread dough; Trace misc. note of bubble gum. The flavor is lightly sweet, moderate bitterness that grows heavy, finish is shorterlightly bitter, lightly acidic. Nets out a touch watery. The body is light, the texture is watery and the carbonation is lively.

Pours a clear pale gold with a nice pillowy white head. Nose is full of lemon zest and hops. Nice tingly mouthfeel. Light malts with lemon and hops on the tongue. Nice dry and peppery finish. Pilseners are probably one of my least favorite styles, but I can tell this ranks right up there with the best of them.

Tap at Barley Johns.  Clear, pale, golden with a frothy white head.  Butterscotch, banana, lemony aroma.  Has flavor qualities similar to a white wine like citrus with a buttery, dry mouthfeel, like Reisling, maybe.  Very stylish and interesting, this is the best pilsener i know of.

Very clear golden, yellow color with a foamy white head.  Crsip citrus aroma with floral hints.  Great bitter citrus and floral hops balanced nicely by light malt character.  Although its not my favorite style this is a great pilsner.

Bottle.  Very light gold color with a fluffy white head, mostly lasting.  Light malt and lemony hop aroma.  Not a skunk within miles. Crisp light citrus (lemon/lime) hop flavor showcased well on top of a pristine light malt body.  Palate light but not watery.  This is as good an American pilsner as youll probably find anywhere if not better.   Great to recommend to ale-phobic macro-lager drinking mates as a quality alternative.

My favorite pils to date. Clear crisp, hopped, citrus flavor. Its a beautiful beer to look at: slightly hazey,bright gold with a thick, blonde head and firm carbonation. I would say this is a pilsner set apart from many others, and a delicious beer regardless.
Bottle. Pours clear gold, white head. Aroma is malt and slightly citrus. Flavor is the same and a little metallic & skunky. Im not a big fan of pilseners anyway.
UPDATED: DEC 22, 2006 I dont drink much Pilsener, prefering IPA, but this an excellent brew. I would sure rather have a HopDevil however.

UPDATED: APR 15, 2007 Pours a light gold color with small fizzy white head.  Citrus, hoppy, and somewhat skunky aroma.  Flavors of herbal grains, hops, and citrus.  Very easy to drink.  I tasty pilsener.

In the nose we have pine, lemon detergent and grains. Pale, almost murky golden with a thin foamy head, somewhat lasting. Tastes frankly incredible, like a jacked up German pils replete with citrus flavours and a ton of hops. Very well-malted as well. Honey flavours round out the bitterness and noticeable alcohol. An excellent, stylish, imaginative beer.

12 oz bottle. Clear pale gold, small white head. Grainy, hopped up cirtus nose. Flavor is a tad on the grainy side, sweet malt notes. Hops come back in the finish, an herbal bitter, and more grain. Very good pils!
Bottled.  Poured a clear golden color with minimal head.  Malty aroma almost sweet.  Has a fairly rich and hoppy flavor with a long finish.

UPDATED: OCT 2, 2006 12oz bottle at Williams in Uptown, Minneapolis. Poured gorgeous, bright straw-blonde into a shaker glass with a small, creamy white head and a hint of chill haze that quite enhanced the color. Aroma is wonderful without being too obtrusive: crisp and lightly hoppy, pleasant teensy whisp of DMS. Flavor is bitter and fairly crisp with just the right faint touch of DMS. Bright hop bitterness but not quite the clean, spicy hop flavor Id expect in a pilsner. There is a surprising rich maltiness but without sweetness. Finish is moderately long and dry, quite refreshing, with lingering bitterness. Palate is rich and velvety but not heavy, very surprising and quite nice (though it does make the beer a bit less quaffable than a traditional pils). Overall the hop flavor is somewhat lacking the classic pilsner character but the beer is otherwise superb.
After finishing the glass, I noticed "Enjoy By Nov 21 05" on the label, which may explain the missing hop flavor. I hope to try a fresher bottle sometime, because I was very impressed on the whole.
Subsequent fresher bottles have showed excellent spicy hop character. This is probably my favorite beer suitable for everyday drinking with food (sorry, Stone IPA!)

Pours out a clear golden with a small white head.  Aroma is of hops and grainy malts.  Surprisingly full-flavored, very hoppy, with nice malt character to it as well.  Medium-bodied, long dry finish.  This is a great pilsener.

UPDATED: SEP 5, 2006 yeah, ill agree this is a pretty good pils.  mostly because its got some good suggestion  of american hops.  slightly watered down.  i dont care for it much.  im done with pilseners.

clear yellow body that was almost glowing.nice white head that sat down very fast.i detect some citus type hops blended with some earth and wheat in the aroma.flavor mixes up the same with the hops comming out a bit stronger in the finish.the mouthfeel is nice and crisp and the palate is very complex for a pilsner.excellent work by the victory people.
Bottled.  Pours a pale golden color with a pretty thick white head.  Good combination of hops and malts, pretty sweet taste, very similar in style to other pilsners.  I recommend this brewsky.

Bottle.  Poured a super pale clear golden brew with a thin off-white head.  A potent grassy aroma of barley, did not pick up much hops in the aroma, but they hit you upfront as you take a sip.  A nice sweet hoppiness that gives way to a quintessential pilsener taste that lingers.  With a silky smooth palate this makes a great beer to grab another of.

Draft.  Aroma:  A nice grainy malt aroma, honey, light lemon, and a good floral and grassy hop aroma.  Appearance:  Classic straw blond pilsener color.  Pretty clear.  Head was white and rocky and lasted for a little while.  Flavor:  Nice malt flavor up front with some sweetness that tasted of honey.  Hops come on soon after.  Lots of floral and grassy flavors, with a lemony flavor that builds as it finishes.  Good clean, crisp flavor.  Palate:  Light bodied.  Carbonation was right on.  Good dry finish which left the palate clean and refreshed.  Overall: I havent had a pilsener this good in a long time.

Light yellow/straw color.  Nicely carbonated.  Nice foamy head with great retention.  Delicate hop aroma with a very small hint of lemon.  Good hop flavor with a fair amount of bitterness that starts at the beginning, continues through the finish, and then lingers on the back of the tongue.  I think this is a pretty good pilsner - crisp, refreshing, good body, and some bitterness.  

12 oz bottle, $1.65 from Rivers Bend.

12oz bottle poured a clear yellow/gold with a small white head. Aroma is subtle hops with a nice crisp malt presents. Taste has a strong bitterness that lingers to the end and a big dry finish. A good Pils to be lagered for some time definitely would be nice to dull some of the hops for the style.

clear and orangish yellow beer with a white head.  fresh aroma of straw, citrus, lager yeast, and grass.  Clean and mostly unoffensive straw and grassy flavors but with slightly fuelish lager yeast undertones and hops that are somewhat muddled.  Crisp ending but lasting semi-bitter lager fuel aftertaste

Ive had this beer numerous times and forgot to rate it which is a crime given its refreshing pure well balanced flavor and sharp cascade-like aroma. Everything seems well balanced from the finish to the flavor. In the aftertaste, there is a bit of grassiness going on amongst the bitter hops which flow. The aroma sends me a sensation of lemon herb but overall the passion of the beers zest doesnt cause me to send it in the 4+ range.

Pours a light yellow gold with a white head.  Smells like light warm malt, lemon and a note of floral hops.  Light brwady malt flavor with citrus, a note of honey and a prominent hop bitterness.  Surprising amount of body for a pilsner and a dry finish.

UPDATED: JUN 26, 2012 Re-rating this.  Cant believe how much Ive come to enjoy this beer.  Prima is simple in many ways, but a has a ton of flavor for a pilsner.  Great hop presence with just enough biscuity malt flavor in the background to balance it out.  Incredibly crisp and refreshing.  Love this beer.

Light and refreshing, especially for the dog days of summer. Crisp beer with a noticable hop presence. Low alcohol content makes for a great session beer. This beer is solid, and one of the best pilseners that I have had.

I have had this beer a number of times. It always goes down too darn quickly for me to get any sort of notes on it. Mighty tasty stuff. This time I held back to take these notes:

Appearance: Pours a lemon straw yellow color with a semi hazy body and a big white head. 

Smell: Lemon grain and herbal hops. It is clean and certainly hoppy. Just what I expect from a German Pilsner. Its that spicy Saaz that just tickles my nose and the anticipation builds. 

Taste: No disappointment here. This beer is packed full of flavors and depth (for a Pilsner especially). It has a solid malt backbone (with a dash of sweetness) that holds it together and of coarse spices and grassy Saaz hop bitterness that is bold but not cloying. The aftertaste is the best part of this beer. It sticks with you relentlessly and beckons for the next sip. Thus the drinkability! WOW!

Mouthfeel: Incredibly smooth and crisp with a very dry finish. Superb!

Drinkability: Dont mess around this beer is like Pringles; once you pop you cant you cant stop. Make sure you have plenty cuz after one youll want more. This beer is built for sessioning, parties and *DRINKING!* 

Hope this is helpful.
Cheers!
Tastl like a real good lager.  Excellent balance of malt and hops.  Sparkling, clear gold appearance.

[bottle] Nice, stardard pils aroma. Flavors are initially quite malty- with some grass or hay. Finishes crisp and dry- very hoppy indeed. Though not my favorite style, I would gladly drink this again.
Poured a clear golden color, coarse foamy head.  Nice light hoppy aroma...generally a pretty hoppy flavor as well, but I could detect some nice malt flavors underneath.  Very good.
Beatiful golden color.  Nice strong assertive hops.  Finish is a nice hoppy bitter and long long lasting.

Out of a 12 0z ice cold bottle poured a golden brew with a nice white head.The aroma was of an abundant amout of noble hops with an underlying sweet maltiness.It was smooth on entry with a crisp bite of hoppiness.A very nice pilsener indeed.
Golden appearance.  carbonation and medium bitterness gives it a distinct flavor. Earthy hops and dry malt - very crisp.. Excellent Pilsner!

UPDATED: MAR 16, 2014 11/05 Hopleaf-10.5oz pour. Clear gold color. Clean aroma with a nobleish hops aroma, also a touch of lemon and vanilla. Taste is light malts with a good hoppiness and bitterness. Noble hops flavor. Finish is lingering mild to moderate bitterness and lingering hops flavor. A very good pils.
  I have drank a lot of this beers since I rated it and never bothered to re-rate it, until now. Floral and herbal hops, clean fermentation character and some light cracker-like malt. Bracing bitterness, good attenuation. Refreshing and lovely. One of my favorite beers.

UPDATED: DEC 19, 2006 My first pilsener, so I dont have much of a grasp on the style.  Aroma was very hoppy, sensed a little grass.  Light yellow with a snow white head.  Nice and smooth on the way in and finishes hoppy and dry.  I enjoyed this quite a bit and sure wouldnt mind having it again.
UPDATED: APR 26, 2007 Not a big Pilsner fan - but at least this is a real pilsner with a nice, hoppy profile. Pleasant malt taste and aroma as well Very refreshing on a hot day.
straw color with a small off white head.  Aroma is hoppy, grassy, and slightly earthy, with a bit of malt thrown in.  Taste is nice, smooth malts with a dry and hoppy earthy finish.
From bottle.  Soft yellow pour with fluffy white head.  Nose is a hay and grass mixture with sweet malts.  Flavor is light and crisp, following nose with a bitter finish.
12 oz Bottle. Pours out a nice yellow. Topped off with a tall white head. That last and last. There is some grass and a nice malt.

Pours a golden-yellow with a white head that leaves a fair amount of lacing. Has a bright hop aroma. The flavor is light, crisp, and dry, and big with a good malt backbone sort of hiding behind the hops. It leaves a wonderful bitter aftertaste reminiscent of celery. A fantastic pilsner and a wonderful gift, wish I had 5 more.
Bright yellow/gold. Modest, frothy, white head. Flavor and aroma of crisp, grainy malt and grassy hops. Dry finish. Light, well carbonated palate. Excellent pilener.

Not a big fan of the style, but always willing to give things a shot. Pours a very pale gold. Lots of bubbles, some white fluffy head. Some typical hops, grass, and pepper in the aroma. Very crisp and smooth. Grassy, some Saaz here and there, decent malt. Not bad. A sessioner by all means.
floral, grass, herbs, pale, clear, aminimal head, white foam, medium sweetness, light body, oily feel, soft carbonation,

I havent ever had a pilsner that I was head over heals about but this was definately a solid beer.  A thin, bright white, moderately carbonated head with a lemony, grassy aroma.  Smooth, light feel in the mouth with a strong hoppy punch at the finish.  No skunk involved.  A repeat buy.

Pours a cloudy, light golden color with fairly thick head.  Slight floral aroma with a hint of sweetness.  Flavor is well balanced and light with a bit of bitterness. Im not a huge fan of pilsners so Im probably not a great judge, but this is definitely one of the superior pilsners Ive had the pleasure of drinking.  Still, not my favorite style though.
UPDATED: JUL 2, 2006 Aight.  Not a good beer compared to the rest of the victories.

UPDATED: DEC 1, 2009 Had to try this once again after a disappointing first attempt a year ago.  The aroma is powerful and pleasant, almost a minty.

Pale gold with filmy white head.  Color belies the rich flavor.  Quite a malty taste and a pleasant bitterness in the aftertaste.  Darn good brew.

From 12oz Bottle.  Nice, even consistency with a finger of brilliant white head resting on top of the clear golden body.  Pleasant, mildly floral aroma presents some grassy hops mingling with an under-ripe strawberry fruitiness.  Thin, crisp mouthfeel, but quite appropriate for the style.  Clean, light, refreshing beer with a spotless hoppy finish.  Drinking this beer makes me quite sad, actually.  Why is the American public forcefully subjected to consume the horrible mass produced pale lagers on the market?  This beer is a fabulous example of an everyday drinking beer that anyybody could enjoy at anytime or occaison, be it at the bar, after a sporting event, or as a refreshing dinner drink.  But no, we are not so lucky.  Clean, refreshing, easy drinking pilsner with nothing wrong with it.  Very well done.

Medium-head of off-white color subdues a strong floral nose with a distinct bready malt character. Body is medium with a fair amount of carbonation. Flavor begins and lingers with citrus/floral hops that overshadow the malt backbone. Strong chewy weight to the flavor makes it a pleasure and drink. Certainly well-hopped, a creative American variation on the style.

Update June 05 on draft: This beer was far superior on draft than in a bottle and was somewhat enjoyable after a summer outing. The grassiness was much toned down on draft and the overall flavor was crisp and refreshing. The bottle version I had in fall of 04 was much less impressive and watery tasting (grassy too).
A great new beer to try, I have tried a lot of new beers and varieties lately and I will buy this one again.  Great stuff!

Bottle courtesy of the Syles and Philip. Pours translucent yellow, giving way to a one inch froth. Lots of spider-web lace here floks. Garden floral aroma pairs up well with the sazzalicious infusion in my nose. Bready notes follow, with honey and pepper. These notes are all subtle, and mingle well together. Fresh hops flavour with mild bitterness is welcome. Flavours also consist of bready, malted out sweetness and a touch of peppery grassy to finish. Crisp and refreshing. Nice summer beer!

Victory Prima Pils
28 May 2006
Bottle (fresh from the brewery)
Golden, very clear.  Big-bubbled head to begin with, but is gone in no time.  Grassy aromas.  Flavors are very dry and crisp, with noticeably more hop presence (again, green and grassy) than you would expect in your average pilsener.  Very refreshing for a hot summer evening.  Pilsener isnt one of my favorite styles, but this is a rendition I could enjoy fairly regularly.

Good good pilsener. Pours beautiful golden with a nice head. Aroma is spicy hops and sweetness. Flavor is a bit strong on the hops actually, very peppery and biting, but enjoyable and pleasant none the less.
a good pilsner, great bright yellow pour with a thick white head.   a bit hoppy, malty, but balanced.  it gets a bit more bitter at the finish.
UPDATED: NOV 21, 2006 Excellent taste, smooth, flavorsome with out being overwhelming, I can see what the person who mentioned banana bread means.  Worth a trip to Philly.

12 Oz. Bottle. Fuming pour of milky hazed yellow-green neon, with a nice finger of dense crisp white head. Aroma is a soft subtle touch of sweet grains and mild bread. A hint of lightly ascerbic metallic-like hop currents flow gracefully. Flavor is a brawny kick of sweetened grain, in very classical fashion. It exhibits a surprising level of strong grain alcohols and rounding chewy oats. Decent depth of flavor, combined with light intricate fusels and a decently balanced wisping vapors of lemony dry hops. Not complex, as expected, but exemplary for the style and incredibly drinkable.

Draught at The Federal in Durham, NC. Pours a golden yellow with a thin white head. Aroma is strong with grassy hops and grains. Sharp grassy hop flavor with just enough German malt to smooth things out. Surprisingly hoppy for the style and refreshing. One of those ultimate lawn mower beers.

Bottled. Pours a light golden color with a medium sized white head. Slightly sweet grainy aroma. Some creaminess along with a sweet floral quality. Creamy mouthfeel. Good maltiness. Slightly hoppy graininess. Somewhat bitter finish with a little graininess. Nice Pils.
Bright aroma of sour corn.  Am I supposed to like this? Pale yellow in color with a thin, white head.  Crisp flavor, lemon, corn, malty, touch of sourness. I like it. Watery texture, very nice.
Fizzy yellow color with a thin white head. Aroma of sweet corn and grain. Sweet corn flavor with some grass and light hops.

UPDATED: OCT 3, 2006 12 oz bottle

Aroma / Appearance - One finger head lingers over a golden, actively carbonated body that reminds me of banana nut bread, wheat, hops and also maintains a general light airiness.

Flavor / Palate - Slightly bitter first impression is a taste of what comes afterwards.  A balance of malts, hops and wheat combines to form an interesting and strong taste that eventually yields to pine nuts, rose petals and dogwood.  Overall, fairly good but for some reason it did not impress me.  Still a very solid pilsener that one could drink all summer.
Straw gold color with a weak layer of film. Aroma is full of malt grain, and hops. Flavor was strong for a pils with a lot of sourgrass, malt, grain, and bread. I wasnt to fond of this pils.

Pours an extremely pale straw color with a nice head, leaving lots o lace.    Aroma is floral, grassy, and spicy with some malty, grainy notes.  Flavor is dominated by herbal, spicy hops and almost has a touch of mint.  Dry mouthfeel with piney hop resins and spice in the aftertaste.  This beer is a hands-down extremely refreshing, excellent pils.
Superb.  Probably the best pilsener I have ever had.  Very firm, crisp hops.  A triumph of brewing.

Pours a solid golden in the glass with a diminishing head and spider lacing.  Nose consists of pine and floral hops.  Flavors are quite nice... they are of bitterness, with pine and spice overtones.  Very crisp mouthfeel with a nice long hoppy finish.  This is the second in the sampler case I bought, and I must say it kicks the V Lager in the teeth... MUCH better offering here... My faith is beginning to restore.

Clear yellow pour, looks like most any other pilsner out there, but with higher than average carbonation. Light malt on the nose, mixed with subtle hops aroma. Grassy flavor with big hops finish. A fine pilsner.
Watery yellow with a small, white head.  Full bodied hoppy aroma.  Slightly piney floral flavor that makes a dry lasting impression on the palate.  Definitely worth a go.

Im sure there are better pilsners out there, but none so widely available.  Incredibly well balanced, predominantly green/natural flavors, Ive never had a beer so refreshing.  I never imagined a beer could BE so refreshing.  The ultimate summer beer, hands down.

Pours yellow with big carbonation and a light head.  It has a light grain and grass aroma with hints of yeast and (almost) banana like hints.  Lightly sweet too.  Not a bad tasting brew.  Simple with light grain and ample (though not over done) hop bitterness (noble and spicy).  Crisp full body.  An easy drink, but not worth the $9.00/6pk if you ask me.
Pours a pale pale yellow...low head but OK lacing...smells kind of sweet....quite quite bitter...this was alitttle better than expected but still really lame.

This beer is often over shadowed by Victorys flagship Hop Devil, but Prima has always been one of Victorys most impressive beers, and one of its originals. This beer is a German Pils by style, and it is an outstanding domestic example with lots of great noble hop aroma, and bitterness, with excellent pilsner malt flavor. This beer pours to a beautiful, bright yellow color, with a thick and creamy, bright white head, and a lively carbonation. The nose on this beer is excellent with fragrant herbal/grassy hop aroma. The palate is firm with crisp pilsner malt flavor, on a clean and smooth body. Prima ends with great pilsner malt flavor up front, then ends with pungent, zesty, herbal hop bitterness that lingers. A natural with German fare, and fish dishes, this one would also match well with Chinese or Thai. Great beer from a great brewery.
6 pack. Darn good Pils. Very crisp and clean. Good for a hot day. Will drink again any day.

Nice aroma for a pilsner.  Overwhelming saaz hops on the aroma.  Still had some o that swill smell, but it was more like outdoor aromas, like hay and grass.  Slight syrupy texture and flavor, along with LOTS of saaz in the flavor, grass, hay, alfalfa, and all in all, it made me think this would be like the king of lawnmower beers.  Ill take this any summer day in the sun.

Pours yellow with a small head and moderate carbonation.  Aroma has clean malts and light spicy hops.  The beer is very light and crisp with a nice amount of carbonation.  There are clean refreshing malts first and then a nice floral hop finish.  An overall refreshing beer that is also high on flavor.  Too bad more pils arent like this - very nice beer.

UPDATED: MAR 28, 2007 Bottle.
Very good pils. Sweet aroma, pours a great head with a great bubbly look. Flavor is fantastic and very drinkable, very enjoyable. A good all around beer. Cheers!
UPDATED: APR 26, 2006 Bottle sampled with Stegosaurus. Pours  golden with a white head. Aroma of hops, citrus and yeast. Flavor is smooth with a bitter finish. Ok didnt like the finish.
Light golden color with a very light head.  Light spicey hop aroma and flavor.  Light malt background  Light to medium body.  Easy to drink beer.
cloudy yellow brew...... decent pilsner, very smooth... light head. Hoppy aroma

[Taster  Portland Oregon, Spring Beer Festival]
This was a very easy to drink deep yellow brew.  Very light head but was a good flavorful summer drinkable brew.  Liked the hops and the malts used I would have another after I mowed the lawn.
12oz bottle: Pours a very light golden yellow color, almost no white head, diminishing.  Very malty aroma.  Hoppy malty smooth balanced flavor, slight malt aftertaste.

Bottle best by May 2006 (rated in April 06).  Pours a very lightly hazy golden yellow with a small white head.  Aroma of sweet malts, honey, grains and some light hops.  Flavor was dry and bitter.  Also with some citrus, grains and grassiness. Really nice Pilsener (not a style I get too much out of but this was one was very solid).

UPDATED: APR 19, 2006 Pours a clear yellowish color with nice white head.  Aroma is of sweet grain, and fresh cut straw.  Taste is sweetened malt, honey and a muted citrus hop taste  Finish is clean and crisp with a bit of hop bitterness.  This is by far the best pilsner I ever had!  Very taste!

The head has a sweetish texture with a bit of a hoppy mixed with metallic aroma.  Good pils nose in the German tradition.  Light bodied, but supposed to be.  A fine pils - dont look for more.  Reminds me of when I was a little kid and my Grandfather would have Knickerbocker & Rheingold at his tavern in NYC back when they were solid brews.
12oz bottle.  Hazy and golden with a kind of dull appearance.  Strong malt nose with a good dose of grassy hops.  Crisp and dry.  Citrus hoppy with a sweet malt character.
Prima has a pleasent hoppish aroma.  The pour is a light golden with a decent white head and lacing.  The flavor is crisp and clean with the bitterness of the hops coming through very nicely.

Pours a slightly cloudy yellow with big ol white head.  Aroma of honey.  Flavors of Saaz hops followed by some more IPA-like hoppiness, finished off with some grapefruitiness and a nice malty finsh.  When I reach for a pilsner, its either this or Pilsner Urquell.

(Bottle (best by 6/15/06) from <A HREF=http://www.ratebeer.com/Place/massachusetts/w target=blank>Julios Liquors) Hazy pale yellow pour with a large white foamy head. Great aroma of honey and sweet hay. Not much lacing. Mouthfeel is smooth, on the light side but still somehow full. Perfect carbonation. Flavor is a perfect honey and malt sweetness that finishes with a pleasant hop bitterness. Very well-balanced. Great flavor and very easy to drink. Nice honey aftertaste. Memorable. Would be an excellent everyday beer.

UPDATED: APR 20, 2006 Understandably, the second highest rated Pilsener on this site.  The relative carbonation, and crispness of a lager; but the a pleasant hoppiness of a mild IPA.  Well-balanced, with a nice malt note.
Wow - didnt know you could get a pilsener like this in a bottle! Clear, pale color. Huge Saaz aroma and flavor. Moderate bitterness (high for a pils.)
Very fizzy and a little hazy.  A light gold with bit of hazyness.  Very light and crisp with no real bitterness (despite the hop on the label).
user_location: Peoples Republic of Athens, Ohio, USA

text:
Mar. 18, 2006; 12 oz. bottle

Enjoy by Dec 16 05.  Ive apparently picked this up three months too late?  Pale & light -- it doesnt look like much -- nevertheless, it is a very good  pilsener (admittedly, not my favorite style).  I do love hops, though; and the bitterness that washes over the palate and then lingers is delightful.  There is just enough of a malt subtext to this brews personality to make the experience truly satisfying . 

A great session choice, and an excellent vehicle by which to introduce your macro-swilling friends to better beer.
Excellent pilsner that I got on tap at the new Eddie Georges Grill 27. Very solid hoppy flavor but was altogether balance very well. I would definetly drink this again if I was looking for a pilsner.

12 oz bottle.  Enjoy by Nov 04 05, hmmm...  Shoots up a big head.  Leaves a chunk of white cotton candy atop a clear straw-colored liquid.  Smell is grass, wheat and lemon.  Starts almost tasteless, like a mineral water, then peppery with mild grapefruit and quinine.  Very smooth medium light body; a little oily.  Just the right amount of tiny bubbles to keep it refreshing.  Clean finish with just a bit of back-tongue hops.  Where did it all go?

bottle, best buy is coming soon, so maybe that was why it didnt quite meet expectations.  dont get me wrong, it was quite good.  crisp and thirst quenching with bitter finish, but not really a standout.

"everyone says this is better on draft, man i hope so. Poured light light gold color. Aroma was grassy and citrus. Flavor was overwelmed by grassy hops. Almost skunky. Will try on tap but no more of this from a bottle. "

Whoa, so I am searching for a pilsner that I had the other day and I find that I have not yet rated this bad boy. Actually this is one of, if not my top, favourite pilsners. Pours clear and somewhat thin slight hops and malts but well balanced and clean. Excellent pilsner.
Bottle. Not the kind of brews I usually drink but I think if all Pils were made like this I would drink them more. Crisp, light, and happy.
For a pilsner not to bad, not an american standard by no means. Lightly ciitrusly flavor , see through glass(w/ the beer in it). Very decent beer from Victory, but not my woman.

12 oz Bottle: Pours a very intersting look.  Very pale yellow and hazy, but with no sediments.  The color is very thin, it almost looks watered down and looks like pee.  The only keeping this from getting a 1 is the thick fluffy cloud-like white head emits from the pour to a three finger hieght.  The aroma is of hops, citrus, alcohol, bread, malts, dreid grass/hay, flowery, quite nice.  The flavor is nice, consisting of lemon, grass, bread, malts and it finishes hoppy.

This is my favorite Pilsner/regular lager Ive had.  Light gold with a well retained, small white head.  Aroma is full of wonderful hops, germanic in character with perhaps a little citrus in there.  Taste is wonderful and balanced with complex, soft and bready malts, rich without being too sweet, classic pilsner style hopping with tones of herbs and subtle citrus.  Definitely an american take on Pilsner.  On the light side of medium bodied, and very smooth with a crisp finish.  Id agree with the commercial description that theres something elegant about this beer.  Its also my new "most refreshing" beer, just edging out Fullers London Pride, and will be bought again for post-lawn work relaxation on beautiful summer nights.

UPDATED: JUL 26, 2009 Bottle thanks to Kramer17801. I have had this at the brewery, but have never rated it. Pours light gold, with diminishing white head. Aroma is malty, herbal, with some notes of hay. Texture is medium light with average carbonation. Great sweet malt and pilsner flavor, balanced by some aggressive Euro hop characteristics. Finish is crisp and thirst quenching. A great american pilsner, coming from someone who does not drink them on a regular basis
Very clear with just a slight aroma of straw.  Flavor is very basic pilsner but then the hops are very overwellming.

Bottle.  Ahh, a beer the color of pee...what could be more appetizing?  Does have a nice frothy white head though.  Sweet malts and mild hops in the aroma.  Taste follows with a classic German pils bitter aftertaste.  Alright.

Had  this beer before,foggyness is gone,so is the flavour and hops.I 
guess its back to the Czechs.Look
to Victorys other brews,pass on this one.

Courtesy of Duane.

Aroma is slightly sulpher tinged and sharp with hops. Lemonade yellow with a huge three finger thick head that is frothy and bubbly. Fore is grainy/malty with a lot of sweetness from that malt. Hop profile is lower than I thought it would be. Definitely a great warm weather beer here as it is quite quenching.

There is no other pilz Ive ever had...maybe Live Oak..that comes close to this one. It might sound ridiculous to say this about a beer but this one is a serisou testament to restraint and subtlety. Even though it explodes in your mouth and rakes your nose, this beer is elegant and powerful. Id compare it to an olympic track athelete. Straw-golden pour; white fluffy head. Hop slice in the nose that fades into a faint and floury dough. Savory edge. No sweetness. That is what makes this thing exquisite. The paper-thin malt and the lean and mean hops unite in the nose to create something divine. When you drink this beer the first thing you get is a smack upside the head. Your mouth is jarred awake. Then however, as the carbonation deflates in your mouth, the hops slide down the walls of your palate  and gracefully...gracefully settle into your jaw. This is powerful. This is extremely inspiring and great. I LOVE THIS BEER!
Bottle @ Oliver Twist, StockholmVery german, this one. Plus some fruity aroma and taste plus a big bitterness in aftertaste.  Pretty standard. Nothing extra.

12 oz bottle  Pours a clear yellow with a good white head.  Good lacing and head lasts well.  Aroma is of hay, straw and grass.  Taste is crisp and clean with a nice finish.
